Mrs. Blair announced with excitement. 'I haven't eaten since breakfast, except for two cups of beef-tea. Are you joining me for lunch, Miss Beddingfeld?' 'Well,' I hesitated."

We stood face to face, locked in a fierce gaze of animosity. It was the first time I truly observed his features - the closely cropped dark hair, the angular jawline, the scar on his tan cheek, and his piercing light grey eyes that held a hint of reckless disdain. There was an undeniable air of danger that surrounded him. "You haven't even said thank you for me saving your sorry life," I taunted with feigned sweetness, delivering a blow that made him visibly recoil. I sensed his deep aversion to acknowledging his debt to me, but I relished in his discomfort. The desire to inflict pain upon him consumed me like never before. "I wish you weren't around to save me in the first place!" he exclaimed with explosive frustration.

As Lord Yardly and I stood in the dimly lit room, a sudden darkness enveloped us. The sound of a door slamming echoed through the silence, followed by a chilling scream that sent shivers down our spines. "Maude!" Lord Yardly exclaimed, his voice filled with fear. Panic set in as we fumbled in the dark, attempting to reach the source of the disturbance. Finally, we located the door and flung it open. The scene before us was horrifying - Lady Yardly lay motionless on the cold floor, a red mark marring her pale throat where her necklace had been violently torn away. Unsure if she was alive or dead, we hovered over her, waiting for any sign of life. Slowly, her eyes fluttered open, revealing the fear and pain hidden within.

“May I inquire as to your identity?” Poirot asked, taking a step closer and nodding respectfully. “I do hope that your husband won’t catch a cold. I couldn’t help but notice that he was wearing slippers and a rather warm dressing-gown.” “Who are you and what do you want?” demanded the woman, her voice filled with suspicion. “It is unfortunate that we have not yet had the pleasure of meeting, madame,” Poirot replied apologetically. “Especially considering that one of our party has traveled all the way from New York just to see you.” Suddenly, the curtains were drawn back and the figure of the Italian man emerged. To my dismay, I saw that he was holding my gun, which Poirot must have accidentally left behind in the taxi.

It was well past midnight when I stood on the deck, gazing at the luminous wake left by the boat. The outline of Africa loomed in the distance, drawing closer as we sped through the black sea. In that moment, I found myself engulfed in a sense of solitude within a magnificent universe. Enveloped by an eerie calm, I lingered there, oblivious to the passage of time, lost in reverie. Abruptly, a strange feeling of imminent peril washed over me. Though there was no sound, a sudden instinct made me whirl around. A shadowy figure had stealthily approached from behind. Before I could react, it pounced. With a firm grip on my neck, it silenced any potential outcry. Despite my frantic struggles, I knew the odds were against me.

That was an undeniable fact. An estate. Perhaps the origin of a noble bloodline. (Lost heir? Title contender?) Or maybe a charming dilapidated building. (Hidden riches?) Indeed, I was leaning towards the notion of hidden treasure. Enigmas always accompany hidden treasure. One step to the east, seven steps to the west, excavate one yard, descend twenty-two stairs. That type of concept. I could develop that later. The priority was to reach Kilmorden Castle promptly. I embarked on a calculated expedition from my quarters and came back loaded with research materials. _Who’s Who_, Whitaker, a Geographical Dictionary, a Compilation of Scottish Ancestral Dwellings, and a Publication on the British Isles. Moments slipped away.

"You never encountered a woman like her before! She must be at least forty, with pince-nez perched on her nose, sensible boots, and an air of brisk efficiency that could be the end of me. A woman with a face as expressionless as a slab of marble." "Do you think she will cling to your arm?" "I sincerely hope not!" Sir Eustace exclaimed. "That would be unbearable. Farewell, enchanting eyes. If I happen to shoot a lion, I will not be giving you its skin after how you have abandoned me." He gave my hand a firm squeeze and we went our separate ways. Suzanne was already waiting for me in the entrance hall. She had come to see me off. "Let's not waste any time," I hurriedly suggested, signaling to the doorman to hail a taxi.

His whole demeanor shifted when he chuckled. His face took on a youthful, joyful, almost unrecognizable appearance. I savored my soup, gently reminding him that he had yet to offer me his counsel. "Ah, indeed, what I meant to suggest was this: If I were in your shoes, I would lay low here until you have fully recuperated. Your foes will assume you perished. They will not be surprised by the absence of your body. It would have been shattered against the cliffs and swept away by the current." A chill ran down my spine. "Once you have regained your strength, you can discreetly travel to Beira and secure passage on a ship bound for England." "That sounds dreadfully dull," I scoffed. "That remark betrays a lack of wisdom."

It remains uncertain how long the girl has been in that place, but it is quite evident that she is not Anne. There is a certain level of discretion when it comes to meddling in the affairs of others. If I were in his shoes, I would not hesitate to remove Race from the island if he dared to pry into my personal matters. The decision has been made, I will depart for Jo'burg tomorrow. Race is adamant that I do so. The situation there is deteriorating, according to reports, so it is best to leave before it escalates further. I am prepared to face the possibility of being shot by a striker. Initially, Mrs. Blair was supposed to accompany me, yet she had a change of heart at the last moment and opted to remain at the Falls.

Nadina, the Russian dancer who had captivated Paris, gracefully acknowledged the applause and disappeared backstage. Her dressing room was filled with bouquets and luxurious garments, as Jeanne, her dresser, chattered on. A knock at the door interrupted them. The mysterious Count Sergius Paulovitch had arrived, a man of elegance and weariness. Switching to English, they discussed the 'Colonel,' a criminal mastermind planning his retirement. Nadina revealed her plan to travel to London incognito, arousing the Count's curiosity. He mentioned a fortune teller's prophecy about the 'Colonel's' downfall involving a woman, sparking Nadina's interest. They speculated on the 'Colonel's' future and the mysteries that lay ahead.

"I consider it my personal property," he stated confidently. However, I viewed the responsibility as the one area where a secretary truly proved their worth. "Let's book an additional cabin," I suggested quickly. The task appeared straightforward, yet Pagett thrived on creating enigmas. The following day, he approached me with the countenance of a Renaissance plotter. "You instructed me to reserve Cabin 17 as an office, correct?" "Yes, what about it? Is the stationery trunk blocking the entrance?" "The doorways are identical in all cabins," Pagett responded gravely. "But trust me, Sir Eustace, there's something unsettling about that particular cabin." Thoughts of The Upper Berth by F. Marion Crawford crossed my mind.

"No, it wasn’t the paper. By the way, do you happen to have it on you? I would quite like to take a look at it." I had brought along the paper as Exhibit A, and I passed it to her. She examined it closely, her brow furrowed. “There’s a dot after the number 17. Why isn’t there a dot after the 1 as well?” “There's a gap,” I observed. “Indeed, there is a gap, but” Suddenly, she stood up and leaned over the paper, bringing it as close to the light as possible. There was a barely contained thrill in her demeanor. “Anne, that’s not a dot! It’s a defect in the paper! A defect in the paper, do you understand? Therefore, you must disregard it and focus solely on the spaces, the spaces!” I rose to my feet and stood beside her.

As I attempted to exit through the hall door, I quickly realized it was not an option. With no other choice, I cautiously made my way up to the attic, tightly securing my restraints before laying back down on the cold floor. I stayed still, anticipating the possibility of being discovered. Thankfully, no one came to investigate. After what seemed like an eternity, I cautiously descended the staircase, only to find the Kafir standing watch by the door, his gentle humming filling the air. Feeling trapped, I retreated back to the attic once more. It was evident that the Kafir was determined to keep a close eye on me throughout the night. I waited in silence as the noises of morning preparations echoed through the house.

I am completely agitated. The dreadful breakfast I had was accompanied by dreadful company. Slow Dutch waitresses served me subpar fish after making me wait. The ordeal of waking up at 5 a.m. to see a doctor upon arrival at the port is exhausting. But now, a serious issue has arisen. I presented Milray’s sealed letter to the Prime Minister, only to find a blank sheet inside. Pagett, a constant source of annoyance, seems pleased by my predicament. Despite my reluctance, I had to entertain his theory about Rayburn. The situation is escalating, and I am eager to leave for Rhodesia. I have made it clear to Pagett that he will not be joining me on this journey. My reputation as an English Member of Parliament is at stake.

I had embarked from Southampton on the 17th, carrying a precious paper that bore the numbers 17, 1, and 22. My deduction was that 17 referred to Cabin 17 and 1 to one o'clock. As tomorrow was the 22nd, I was convinced that something significant would occur at 1 a.m. My evening was restless as I awaited the appointed hour. When it came, I heard the hurried footsteps of a man outside my cabin. Without hesitation, I concealed him from pursuers, all while maintaining the appearance of a lady washing her neck. The unexpected arrival of a stewardess provided a moment of tension, but the drunk intruder in my cabin turned out to have been stabbed. Despite his defiance, I tended to his wound, demanding no gratitude in return.

There it would be impracticable and impossible so the Prime Minister vanishes. The police of this country rush across the Channel, and no one bothers to investigate the details of the first attack. He and the fake chauffeur might be detained as suspicious individuals, but nobody will think to suspect their true involvement in the plot, and they will eventually be set free due to lack of proof.” “And the genuine Prime Minister?” “He and O’Murphy were taken directly to the residence of ‘Mrs.

We raced to Cape Town as soon as possible. Suzanne greeted me there, and together we dismantled the giraffe. Colonel Race suggested we move into Sir Lawrence Eardsley's villa at Muizenberg. Plans were made for me to return to England with Suzanne, getting married in London with the trousseau from Paris. Suzanne loved planning, but the future felt unreal. The night before we sailed, Harry appeared, urging me to run away with him to Rhodesia. I followed him, feeling like a lunatic in love. It's been two years since then, living on the island. Suzanne wrote a letter, calling us lunatics. Another letter arrived from Bolivia, offering me a diary to use as I please. I may now be Lady Eardsley, but the past still haunts me.

He needed to fake his death, escape to a different country with his wife, and change his identity. To make sure his wife had control of the money, he altered his will. A rough tramp intruded into their garden, leading to an unexpected opportunity for the couple. They quickly devised a plan to shift the blame onto the tramp's body, dressing it in the man's clothes and stabbing it with an aeroplane dagger. The husband would then bury the body, ensuring it was found later to divert suspicion. In the meantime, he would disguise himself as the tramp and quietly leave town. However, their carefully laid out plan faced unexpected challenges when a girl named Bella showed up at their door, threatening to unravel everything.

I found myself staring ahead, a sense of confusion settling in. Norman and I were a formidable pair, capable of handling any challenge. Surprisingly, our journey continued northward, bypassing London altogether. This unexpected detour left me bewildered. Gradually, as the car decelerated, the familiar sights of Hendon Aerodrome came into view. Poirot's plan became clear to me in an instant - we were to fly to France. While bold, the idea seemed impractical at first glance. Sending a telegram would undoubtedly be faster. Time was of the essence, and Poirot would have to forego the personal accolades of saving the Prime Minister. As we came to a stop, Major Norman exited the vehicle, replaced by an undercover officer.

I meekly agreed to his request for company, though apprehensive of the consequences. Before his departure, I inquired about his name, to which he casually replied, "Harry Rayburn." The sudden onset of seasickness during the journey left me incapacitated and indifferent to my original mission. However, a kind gesture from Mrs. Flemming led to a change in plans, as I decided to embark on a new adventure in South Africa. With a generous parting gift in hand, I set out on my journey, eventually finding some solace on deck and observing the intriguing passengers around me. The arrival in Madeira brought a glimmer of hope, as the scent of violets lifted my spirits and made me consider enduring the remainder of the voyage.

Just as he approached him, the man glanced quickly up and down the street, then took a small item from his pocket and tossed it over the fence before continuing on to the station. The 'chink' of the object hitting the ground piqued the interest of a man in the ditch, who found a ring. Kellett claims this story, but Lowen denies it vehemently. There is a possibility that he encountered Davenheim in the lane, but Poirot finds it highly unlikely. Japp agrees, noting that Lowen's actions seem odd. Poirot suggests that the ring could have been planted near the scene. Japp mentions a lime kiln nearby that could have been used to dispose of the body. Poirot contemplates the situation, leaving Japp and the narrator puzzled.

Mrs. Davenheim is described as a pleasant but not very bright woman, and it is mentioned that Mr. Davenheim had many financial rivals who may bear ill will towards him. A gardener saw a figure near the rose-garden, and there is speculation about suicide or foul play. Poirot examines a photograph of the missing man and finds the case to be quite obscure. Japp later reveals that Mr. Davenheim's clothes were found near the lake, and Lowen, a suspect, was seen near the study around the time of the disappearance. A pawned ring belonging to Mr. Davenheim further complicates the case. The narrative ends with the introduction of Billy Kellett, who provides a strange account of his activities on the day of the disappearance.

Nadina, a renowned Russian dancer, gracefully accepted the accolades of her adoring audience in Paris. As the curtain fell, she was greeted by the Manager, who praised her exceptional performance. Nadina, accustomed to praise and admiration, made her way to the dressing-room where Jeanne, her loyal dresser, awaited her. Amidst the bouquets and luxurious garments, a visitor arrived - Count Sergius Paulovitch. Switching to English, they engaged in a cryptic conversation about the enigmatic 'Colonel' and his impending retirement. Nadina hinted at a mysterious plan involving a trip to London, leaving the Count intrigued and curious. As they exchanged knowing glances, the future seemed uncertain and filled with intrigue.

"Clearly, Giraud has missed the mark entirely. If Jack Renauld is truly guilty, it is despite Giraud's misguided arguments, not because of them. The most damning evidence against him is a secret that only I am aware of.""What is it?" I inquired, feeling intrigued."If you were to engage your intellect, and analyze the case with the same clarity that I possess, you would also uncover it, my dear friend."Poirot's response irritated me, as usual. Without pausing, he continued, "Let us stroll towards the shoreline. We will perch on that small hill there, with a view of the beach, and reexamine the case. I will share all my insights with you, but I would rather you arrive at the truth independently, without my guidance."

“Have you heard about our new flat, Mr. Parker?” Mrs. Robinson asked excitedly. “It’s in Montagu Mansions, and it's only eighty pounds a year!” “Montagu Mansions? That’s a big building near Knightsbridge, right?” Parker inquired, surprised. Mrs. Robinson nodded, a worried expression creeping onto her face. “Could it be haunted?” Parker dismissed the idea, declaring he had never heard of a haunted flat. “There were a few odd things, though,” Mrs. Robinson admitted. She went on to explain how they found the flat, despite being told it was already taken. After signing the agreement, they were set to move in the following day. “What a strange story,” Poirot pondered, intrigued by the inexplicable cheapness of the flat.

"Consider this," I began, leaning in closer to my colleague. "The evidence strongly suggests that Madame Daubreuil was not the mastermind behind it all. Instead, we must entertain the possibility that Georges Conneau orchestrated the entire scheme. Yes, that's it. Georges Conneau and Madame Renauld working together to commit the crime. But lurking in the shadows, there is a mysterious individual, operating under an unknown alias. Let's retrace our steps in the Renauld Case, starting from the very beginning. Do you have your notebook handy? Excellent. Now, what is the initial event we should document?" "The letter you received?" "While that was our first clue, it doesn't mark the true genesis of this investigation.

The passenger responsible for arranging the transaction went by the name of Carton, and his physical description matched that of the man who met his demise on the Underground. This revelation solved one mystery, revealing that the diamonds were the crucial element in the entire affair. The final days aboard the Kilmorden passed swiftly as we approached Cape Town, prompting me to carefully consider my next steps. There were numerous individuals I needed to monitor closely - from Mr. Chichester to Sir Eustace and his secretary, not forgetting Colonel Race. Determining how to proceed was no easy task. My focus naturally gravitated towards Chichester, leading me to reluctantly consider the fate of Sir Eustace and Mr..

There were no clues to her identity or whereabouts. Mrs. Havering hired Mrs. Middleton as a housekeeper through Selbourne's Agency. However, Mrs. Middleton had no record with the Agency. Poirot suspected foul play and instructed to find out what vehicle took her to Hunter's Lodge, but no leads were found. It was later revealed that Mrs. Havering and her husband were the masterminds behind Mr. Pace's murder and the missing Liberty Bonds. Despite their crimes, justice caught up with them in a tragic accident. Miss Farquhar sought Poirot's help in solving the case of the stolen bonds, involving her fiancé, Mr. Ridgeway. The bonds disappeared mysteriously on board the Olympia, and Poirot agreed to investigate further.

"I was preparing for a lengthy journey, unsure when I would return. It was important for me to see her one last time, to make sure she knew my feelings were unwavering." Poirot maintained unbreakable eye contact as he questioned Renauld's actions. After a significant pause, Renauld finally responded, confirming that he did see her. "What happened next?" Poirot pressed. "I missed the final train, so I trekked to St. Beauvais and managed to secure a car from a nearby garage to transport me back to Cherbourg." "St. Beauvais? That's quite a distance to walk, M. Renauld." "I needed the time to think." Poirot nodded in understanding as Renauld made his exit, grabbing his hat and cane before disappearing into the night.

Lady Yardly was ushered into the room, her dark, flashing eyes betraying her concern. She acknowledged that she, too, had received mysterious letters regarding the diamond, with a hint of Eastern influence. Unfortunately, the letters had been destroyed, leaving them with no further clues. Lady Yardly decided to leave, entrusting Captain Hastings with the information to relay to Poirot. When Poirot returned, he seemed intrigued by the developments and decided to involve Lord Yardly in the investigation. Despite some initial reservations, Poirot was determined to solve the case and protect the family diamond. Lord Yardly, a cheerful and somewhat simple man, was puzzled by the situation, seeking answers from Poirot.

"But all my efforts would have been futile if I had attended. The same goes for those who claim to be 'experts.' Look at the handwriting analysis in the Cavendish Case. One lawyer’s interrogation reveals similarities, while the defense presents evidence of differences. It’s all very technical. And the outcome? Simply confirming what we already suspected. The writing closely resembled that of John Cavendish. And now the mind is left pondering 'Why?' Was it truly his handwriting? Or was someone trying to mislead us? I have unraveled that mystery, my friend, and I have done so accurately." With that, Poirot, having effectively silenced me, if not entirely convinced, reclined in his chair with an air of contentment.

"In the event that you are stopped during your journey, I will furnish you with two distinct permits. One will be authorized by the Union Government, while the other will identify you as a British tourist uninvolved with the Union in any capacity." "A permit for each side, is that the idea?" "Precisely." The task did not interest me as I am familiar with the potential consequences in such scenarios. Confusion inevitably arises, leading to errors. Handing the incorrect permit to the wrong individual could result in my prompt execution by an insurrectionist or a law enforcement officer. I observed the latter patrolling the streets, donning bowler hats, smoking pipes, and casually carrying rifles under their arms.

I couldn't believe my luck when I saw my target casually sipping beef tea by the rail. I approached him with a friendly smile, hoping to smooth things over after the cabin mix-up. Mr. Chichester, however, was not so forgiving. As we exchanged words, I couldn't help but notice that his skin was surprisingly fair for someone who claimed to have spent two years in the depths of Africa. His reaction to a dropped paper only deepened my suspicions. It was clear that Mr. Chichester was not to be trusted. Later, during a conversation about Italy, the strange behavior of Mr. Pagett only added to my growing list of suspects. The more I observed, the more I realized that any one of them could be hiding something sinister.

“No, they’re here right enough. One of the two must have hidden them and it’s very unlikely for the chambermaid to have done so.” Poirot calmly pointed out. The inspector was taken aback by his confidence. Poirot then demonstrated his deductions swiftly, proving that the chambermaid couldn't have hidden the necklace. The inspector, satisfied, continued his search and found the necklace hidden in the maid's bed. Mrs. Opalsen was relieved to have it back, even though Poirot suspected it was an imitation. He decided to keep this information to himself, knowing that the true thief had not been caught. Poirot and his companion left the room, but Poirot's mind was already working on the next steps to solve the case.

His cohorts may have incapacitated him with a cloth and chloroform, but I fail to see what their goal was. He is unlikely to be of any help to them now, as he will be closely monitored until the situation with the Prime Minister is resolved. It's possible that he intended to mislead the police? However, he claims that something was placed over his nose and mouth, and he recalls nothing beyond that. This does not lead the investigation astray; it sounds remarkably truthful. Let's head to the station. France may reveal more clues. Although I have my doubts. It's astonishing that the Prime Minister hasn't been found in such a confined area. If the military and police of two nations haven't located him, how can I?

As we drove around in the afternoon, a flat tire caused a delay. By the time I returned to the Grand Metropolitan, it was already past 8 o'clock. The first thing I saw was Poirot, looking even smaller than usual, standing between the Opalsens with a look of contentment. "My dear Hastings!" he exclaimed, rushing over to greet me. "Give me a hug, my friend; everything has gone perfectly!" Fortunately, the hug was only a gesture, something one can never be certain of with Poirot. "Are you saying" I started. "Absolutely marvelous, I must say!" Mrs. Opalsen chimed in, her chubby face beaming. "I told you, Ed, that if anyone could recover my pearls, it would be him." "You certainly did, my love, you certainly did."

Then, his expression brightening, he hurried over to the desk. Within moments, he was sifting through the deceased man's checkbook. After a moment, he gestured with excitement. The final stub was left untouched. "Courage!" exclaimed Poirot, giving him a reassuring pat on the shoulder. "Undoubtedly, Madame Renauld will have valuable insight into this enigmatic individual known as Duveen." The police commissioner's demeanor lightened. "You're right. Let's move forward." As we prepared to exit the room, Poirot offhandedly mentioned: "This is where M. Renauld entertained his visitor last evening, correct?" "Yes, but how could you possibly know that?" "By this. I discovered it on the rear of the leather armchair."

We drove past the town and reached a fork in the road. A peasant directed us to the Villa Geneviève, but as we looked for it, a girl caught our attention. She was a vision of beauty, with a golden head and anxious eyes. Poirot and I were intrigued by her presence. Suddenly, we were stopped by a sergent de ville who delivered the shocking news of Mr. Renauld's murder. Poirot sprang into action, seeking answers from the authorities. The commissary welcomed us and Poirot revealed that the victim had foreseen his own demise. As we entered the Villa, the examining magistrate was ready to begin his investigations. The crime had occurred in the early hours of the morning, and the mystery was waiting to be unraveled.

I hadn’t meant to disturb him by advertising my presence. But suddenly I heard a light footfall behind me, and his voice broke the silence: “Miss Beddingfeld.” “Yes?” I turned around. “I want to apologize. I behaved like a boor last night.” “It was a peculiar night,” I replied. “You may not know, but you are in danger,” he warned. “They are ruthless. Your only chance is to persuade them they’re mistaken. Be careful, always be on the lookout for danger. If you fall into their hands, tell the whole truth.” “Why warn me?” I asked. “It may be the last thing I can do for you,” he said. “Goodbye,” he said as he left, his footsteps echoing along the deck. I was left alone, wondering about the danger that lay ahead.

I never expected to find myself in such a situation. As a crime novelist, I had always imagined myself writing about thrilling events, not actually experiencing them. But here I was, faced with a wounded man in my cabin on the Kilmorden Castle. The night had taken a turn I had never anticipated. It all started with a number - 17. Little did I know that this seemingly innocuous number would lead me down a path of danger and intrigue. The man before me, wounded and defiant, was a puzzle waiting to be solved. And I, with my histrionic talents and quick thinking, was determined to unravel the mystery that lay before me. It was a night I would never forget, a night that would forever change the course of my life.

Madame Beroldy was the kind of woman who could captivate any man. Her beauty and mysterious aura drew people in, including the wealthy American, Mr. Hiram P. Trapp. But behind closed doors, a dark and twisted plot was unfolding. One fateful night, the Beroldys' home was breached by masked intruders, leading to a gruesome discovery. Madame Beroldy was found bound and gagged, while her husband lay lifeless with a knife through his heart. The investigation pointed towards Madame Beroldy and her alleged lover, Georges Conneau. Despite her royal blood claims and elaborate stories, the truth eventually came to light when a confession letter from Conneau surfaced, revealing the shocking extent of their deadly plan.

Poirot and I had arrived at Marsdon Manor to investigate the death of Mr. Maltravers, who had recently insured his life for a large sum of money. The circumstances surrounding his death seemed suspicious, especially considering his financial troubles. We spoke to Dr. Bernard, the only doctor in the area, who confirmed that Mr. Maltravers had died from an internal hemorrhage. However, the doctor's vague responses raised some doubts in Poirot's mind. Mrs. Maltravers, the widow, was distraught and beautiful, and she shared that her husband had insured his life because he believed he would die soon. Poirot noticed a discrepancy in the case, but before we could investigate further, a tall young man approached us.

"And once again, there was nothing to be found. No balcony in sight." "Even if there was," the inspector remarked impatiently, "I fail to see how that would be of any use to us, given that the maid claims she never left the room." "Of course," Poirot responded calmly, unfazed. "If Mademoiselle is certain she did not exit the room." Before he could continue, the chambermaid and the police searcher reappeared. "Nothing," the searcher stated bluntly. "Well, I should hope not," the chambermaid declared indignantly. "And that French woman should be ashamed for tarnishing an innocent girl's reputation!" "There, there, my dear; it's all right," the inspector reassured, as he opened the door. "No one suspects you."

"I’m certain Colonel Race finds you quite captivating, Anne. Just a few glances from those mischievous eyes of yours, and the trap is set. Everyone seems to get engaged on a cruise. There’s simply nothing else to occupy oneself.” “Marriage is not on my agenda.” “Is that so?” Suzanne questioned. “Why ever not? I find marriage delightful, even with Clarence!” I dismissed her casual attitude. “What concerns me,” I stated firmly, “is Colonel Race's involvement in all of this. He is definitely part of the puzzle.” “Do you truly believe it was mere coincidence, his recounting that tale?” “Absolutely not,” I asserted. “He was observing us all intently. You recall, some of the diamonds were recovered, but not all."

Marthe Daubreuil had a plan, but it was thwarted by a struggle with Madame Renauld. Although Marthe tried to make it look like suicide, she was checkmated by another woman with strong hands. Poirot suspected Marthe from the start, based on her anxious eyes. Madame Renauld's son, Jack, was kept in the dark about his father's past until Poirot revealed the truth. Jack decided to start a new life in South America with his mother. Poirot advised him to be honest with his love interest, Bella, and to ask for her forgiveness. In the end, Poirot received a visit from a film star, Mary Marvell, who was being threatened over a valuable diamond. Poirot advised her to keep the diamond safe until the threat had passed.

“I can’t definitively determine the time of death based on the medical evidence, but it’s clear the victim has been deceased for more than twelve hours. Tell me, do you believe a man stabbed in the heart would fall so neatly with his feet together and arms at his side? No.”

When Poirot advised Japp to arrest the housekeeper, it was too late. Mrs. Middleton had vanished, leaving behind only ordinary clothes. A large settee covered in chintz sat against the wall, while the window seats were also draped in the same faded chintz. Poirot, lighting a cigarette, discussed their plan. “Not a word was shared with me. We never had that kind of relationship. He's like the rest of them, spouting inflammatory speeches for political gain only to backtrack later. I encountered him as he was heading to Cape Town to defend himself in a lengthy Dutch speech.
